data.name: Clock Singularity
data.description:
You are given a certain assortment of clocks. You need to tell me how long it will take for all the clocks to read the same time.

Input

`clocks`: An array of integers, each one representing the maximum value of a clock. After reaching the absolute value (see note below) of it, the clock's time wraps back to 0. - Integers in the `clocks` array may be negative - these represent clocks that run in reverse.

Output

`time`: A non-zero number - the amount of time it will take to reach the Clock Singularity. - The Clock Singularity is the amount of time it will take for all the clocks to reach the same time, after the beginning. - All clocks start at the same time, at zero.

Example

```javascript singularity([2,5,-4]) // 8 ``` ![oops, please raise an issue about this broken image](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/JomoPipi/codewars-images/main/images/clock-singularity.gif) ```javascript /* input: [2, 5, -4] max_values: [2, 5, 4] runs_in_reverse: [false, false, true] Time current_clock_values t=0: [0, 0, 0] <- The beginning, not quite the singularity we're looking for. t=1: [1, 1, 4] t=2: [2, 2, 3] t=3: [0, 3, 2] t=4: [1, 4, 1] t=5: [2, 5, 0] t=6: [0, 0, 4] t=7: [1, 1, 3] t=8: [2, 2, 2] <- The coveted singularity, indeed a rare event. */ ``` # Tests setup: Fixed tests: - 10 tests: `N <= 12`; `X <= 3400` - 2 tests: `N <= 24`; `X <= 128` Random tests: - 40 small tests: `N <= 11`; `X <= 10` - 40 medium arrays tests: `N <= 26`; `X <= 20` - 40 tests - 1 backward clock, 2 forward: `X <= 2500` - 10 tests - 2 backward clocks, 1 forward: `X <= 1000` - 10 tests - 2 backward clocks, 2 forward: `X <= 3500` - 40 large tests: `N <= 6`; `X <= 800` - 40 large tests 2: `N <= 14`; `X <= 50` (where `N` is the number of clocks and `X` the maximum absolute value found in those clocks)
if you're stuck, try this one first.

Goodluck!
